page.title: 14 CUDHAM - CHURCH BELLS
page.content: Cudham church tower,the oldest part of the church, houses ten bells, they are hung in two layers because the belfry space is limited. Reputed to be the 3rd lightest set of ten bells in the country, the smallest (treble) is only 2.5 cwt and the largest (tenor) is 9.5 cwt in weight. The oldest bell was cast in 1490 but others have been added since, the last 4 in 1930. The bells are housed in the steeple with the ringing room directly below and reached by a steep, wooden staircase. Each bell plays a different note (A,B,C#,D,E,F#,G#,A,B,C#). There is a "sally" of wool on each rope so that the ringer's hands are protected from rope burns. The tenor bell chimes each hour, and all the bells are used for services. Bell ringing practice is on Monday nights.
